<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 673, 89]]<|/det|>
A student determines the density of modelling clay by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 203, 120]]<|/det|>
**Method 1**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 912, 152]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows one face of a piece of modelling clay that the student uses. This is sample A.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 161, 599, 291]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 304, 534, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 336, 549, 354]]<|/det|>
The student measures the depth \(d\) of sample A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 361, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ............................... 3.2 ....................... cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 397, 181, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the length \(l\) and the width \(w\) of the sample A of modelling clay. Fig. 1.1 is drawn actual size.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 441, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
<form>l = ......................................................... cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<form>w = ......................................................... cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 552, 181, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 552, 779, 571]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{A}} = l \times w \times d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 618, 920, 640]]<|/det|>
<form>V<sub>A</sub> = .................................................... cm³ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 651, 183, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 651, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.2 shows sample A on a balance. Record the mass \(m_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A to the nearest g.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 680, 641, 856]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 875, 534, 894]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 905, 920, 924]]<|/det|>
<form>m<sub>A</sub> = .................................................... g [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 79, 180, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 870, 103]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}}\) of sample A of modelling clay using the equation \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{m_{\mathrm{A}}}{V_{\mathrm{A}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 109, 920, 145]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this method and include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 186, 920, 207]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho_{\mathrm{A}} =\) ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 220, 203, 238]]<|/det|>
<label>Method 2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 250, 146, 269]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 250, 715, 271]]<|/det|>
The student records the volume \(V_{1}\) of water in a measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 276, 920, 300]]<|/det|>
<form>\(V_{1} =\) ................................................. 150 .................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 311, 920, 346]]<|/det|>
He carefully lowers sample B of the same modelling clay into the measuring cylinder until it is completely covered with water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 358, 774, 378]]<|/det|>
He records the new reading \(V_{2}\) of the water level in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 383, 920, 408]]<|/det|>
<form>\(V_{2} =\) ......................................... 182 .................... $cm^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 420, 181, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 420, 771, 440]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{B}} = V_{2} - V_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 465, 920, 486]]<|/det|>
<form>\(V_{\mathrm{B}} =\) ................................................. $cm^3$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 497, 180, 516]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 497, 601, 516]]<|/det|>
The student measures the mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 522, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<form>\(m_{\mathrm{B}} =\) ................................................. 60 .................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 570, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho_{\mathrm{B}}\) of sample B using the equation \(\rho_{\mathrm{B}} = \frac{m_{\mathrm{B}}}{V_{\mathrm{B}}}\). Give your answer to a

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 605, 798, 625]]<|/det|>
suitable number of significant figures for this method and include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 667, 920, 688]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho_{\mathrm{B}} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 700, 146, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 700, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that the density of modelling clay is not affected by the mass or the volume of the sample used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 745, 920, 780]]<|/det|>
State whether your results agree with the suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to your results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 792, 917, 810]]<|/det|>
statement ............................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 822, 917, 841]]<|/det|>
justification ............................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 870, 920, 889]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 685, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the cooling of water under different conditions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 445, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows the apparatus she uses.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 128, 823, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 387, 534, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 420, 146, 439]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 420, 920, 454]]<|/det|>
The thermometer in Fig. 2.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 458, 855, 500]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 515, 559, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 545, 920, 564]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)  ......................................  [1]

She immediately starts a stopclock. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|> After 180 s, she measures the temperature \(\theta\) shown on the thermometer. Her temperature readings are shown in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 197, 539, 214]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[343, 227, 655, 304]]<|/det|>

Include the unit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 528, 920, 547]]<|/det|> \(R_{1} =\) ................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 559, 146, 578]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 559, 920, 609]]<|/det|> The student empties the beaker. Fig. 3.2 is drawn actual size. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 330, 752, 425]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 438, 534, 457]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 470, 144, 489]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 470, 650, 489]]<|/det|> On Fig. 3.2, measure and record the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 500, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
h_{\mathrm{O}} = .................................................... [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 532, 144, 550]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 532, 841, 550]]<|/det|> The student places the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 562, 171, 581]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 562, 871, 581]]<|/det|> He moves the screen slowly until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 593, 166, 612]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 593, 814, 612]]<|/det|> He measures the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 624, 171, 643]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 624, 920, 657]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure using values of \(u\) equal to \(25.0 \text{cm}\), \(30.0 \text{cm}\), \(35.0 \text{cm}\) and \(40.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 670, 173, 689]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 670, 500, 689]]<|/det|> The readings are shown in Table 3.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 701, 541, 719]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 732, 680, 885]]<|/det|>
\(u/\text {cm}\)\(v/\text {cm}\)\(m\)
20.070.9
25.041.5
30.032.5
35.028.1
40.025.6
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 900, 920, 937]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the magnification \(m\) for each value of \(u\). Use the equation \(m = \frac{\nu}{u}\) . [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 578, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the resistances of different wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 823, 120]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the resistances of wires made from different metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 129, 541, 153]]<|/det|>
Resistance is calculated using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 420, 182]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 196, 211]]<|/det|>
ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 201, 226]]<|/det|>
voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 232, 242]]<|/det|>
power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 205, 257]]<|/det|>
metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 510, 274]]<|/det|>
a selection of wires made from different metals.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 907, 305]]<|/det|>
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 324, 336]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 656, 368]]<|/det|>
• write a list of suitable metals for the wires you will investigate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 801, 400]]<|/det|>
• draw a diagram of a suitable electrical circuit using standard electrical symbols

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 414, 549, 432]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how to carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 445, 485, 462]]<|/det|>
• state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 918, 508]]<|/det|>
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table).

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
